data.title: The Same 80's Recipe
data.text: A blast from the past. I read the other negative reviews but they were wrong . . . It is just as good as I remembered.

data.title: Not like it used to be
data.text: Garcia's Pizza has been a fixture in Bloomington/Normal for over 37 years. First location was across from Watterson Towers on the ISU campus. Big, rectangular slice of thick crust pizza with tasty tomato sauce, lots of cheese and fresh toppings all served in a to-go box.  Not sure how long this Main St location has been in operation. The pizza is still a rectangle. The crust is almost too thick and the sauce was skimpy and not flavorful. The mushroom topping was non-descript. Others in our group ordered the stuffed pizza which had more sauce and received good reviews.  We dined in next door at the pub which has a pass through to Garcia's. Not sure if they still use a box!

data.title: Not what I expected
data.text: Having grown up viewing Garcia's as a real treat, I was so excited about the return of Garcia's to Bloomington. Unfortunately, the level of service provided does not even come close to what I experienced years ago. During our visit, we waited 45 minutes for individual slices of pizza, after waiting 10 minutes just to order. We saw people leave the restaurant after waiting more than an hour because they had not yet received their pizza. We won't be returning.

data.title: Takes Me Back to My College Years
data.text: As a graduate of the University of Illinois, we lived for Sunday! There was no dorm food served. So we always headed over to Garcia's! The pizza is great, and there is a variety of choices! All very good. I am so glad to see it in Bloomington!! I recommend the deep dish!!!

data.title: Ghost town
data.text: Went in to get a slice at 9 at night and no employees around . Waited five minutes and two other groups came in behind us also wanting to eat. A guy came through a door from the back and answered phone and never acknowledged any of us. We waited for him to get off phone and he said they had no pizza ready and it would be a while. Everyone left . Sat night and no pizzas.

data.title: Pizza with a Friend as we Visited Bloomington for the First Time.
data.text: Excellent Thin Crust Pizza. The sauce used was not your standard pizza sauce. Excellent flavoring! We had a large thin crust - 1/2 sausage/green olive and 1/2 mushroom/green olive. Sausage was also unusual and excellent flavor. Mushrooms were fresh (I do not like when canned mushrooms are used!). Best of all, other than the sauce, was the crust - Wow!! Reason had to give a 4 out of 5 rating is due to the tables are not cleaned quickly, at least the day we were there. Garcia's is very busy with takeout orders and people eating in. Just need to be more aware and have staff clean the tables downstairs and would be a clear 5 out of 5 rating!

data.title: Old familiar returns to new place
data.text:
I use to eat at the downtown Normal one across from Watterson Towers when I was younger.

This new location in Downtown Bloomington, brings back the multi-level experience with the video games on both levels.

Still has the familiar lunch-time combos with a slice of pizza and salad!

Glad they returned, but wished it was in Normal!

data.title: Just as I remembered (lest the price)
data.text: All but the cost. Although I have trouble often remembering my youth... I do remember many good times at Garcia's Pizza (back in the 80's) when it was in Normal, Illinois. Surprisingly or not... the pizza taste just as wonderful as I had remembered. Although the price (and I guess as a youth I had never bought anything more than a slice) ...it was $30 for a large Gutbuster :( ...and probably more than what we needed but

data.title: Welcome back!
data.text: I have had fond memories of deep dish pizza from Garcia's back in college at ISU.  I was finally able to confirm that they are truly as delicious as I remembered.  The crust was slightly overcooked but that only minimally decreased my appreciation, and had no effect on my gorging.  Their signature sauce is sweet and unique.  The peppers and onions were fresh.  The cheese was plentiful.  What more can you ask for?

data.title: Wonderful pizza, but Chaos reigns here!
data.text:
Garcia's pizza is still Garcia's pizza, and that's a great thing.  Loved it as a kid, loved that champaign had one (may still) when I was away at school there, and was excited to get it back here in BloNo.  The pizza is still great - so thick, so cheesy, such a good and different sauce, I'm looking forward to ordering again.

However, I was not at all surprised to see the reviews below regarding weird service problems.  I think I waited 45 minutes for a pizza after ordering a simple one-topping to-go when the place was not busy.  The two gentlemen who took and tried to handle my order were old school and one of them may have been one of the original founders - they were polite to me and I so respect the product they bring, but they were so overwhelmed by trying to keep a small number of simple orders straight; then, when a very drunk and confused belligerent started accosting them about his order, it put them right over the edge into total service collapse for the entire restaurant - lots of grumbling people waiting around for pizza they thought they'd have by now.

What this place needs is to keep making the food they're making but, especially if they are going to stay in the downtown bar area, find some good energetic help who can move faster, run the register, and shrug off the antics of the overserved.

data.title: Excited about an old favorite opening back up!
data.text: I visited the new Garcia's in downtown Bloomington as it was always a favorite of mine.  The food was good and the it came out pretty fast.  Staff was nice and helpful.  As far as the restaurant itself, I was just hoping for a more nostalgic feel when I walked in (similar to the Garcia's restaurants in the past). but it is pretty plain.  Anyhow, good pizza, and good service and I'll be back.

data.title: It Ain't Like It Used to Be
data.text: Went for lunch last week to the newly opened Garcia's Pizza in downtown Bloomington.  Boy was I disappointed!  Ordered a slice of the Gutbuster with salad and soft drink.  The restaurant is really laid out in a weird configuration. On the main floor there are 4 booths and a couple of tables and downstairs are tables and several pinball machines.  Big screen TV's are on both levels.  Waited abut 20 minutes for my slice to be delivered to my booth and it was nothing like I remember from the stores in Bloomington back in the 80's.  The pizza tasted like it had been frozen and then warmed up.  As I picked it up to take a bite, the bottom crust stuck to the rectangle plate and the toppings spilled all over the tray. The salad was served on a regular size paper plate with plastic over it.  It looked like it had been sitting in the cooler for a while.  Not really fresh and was somewhat wilted. The veggies, cucumber, carrots and tomato were quite watery. Not very appetizing.  There also wasn't enough dressing. The small cup of ranch was only enough for about half the salad. I didn't eat much of it as I had to pick my way through the brown lettuce and limp veggies.  I did get a knife and fork and eat about half of the Gutbuster.  The flavor was there, but again it tasted like it had been warmed up not baked in a pizza oven.  Too bad the old Garcia's atmosphere and fresh flavors were not present the day I was there.

data.title: Inconsistant pizzas, poor service
data.text:
12/22/2015 Our son had been looking forward to having a Garcia's gut-buster pie since he found out that they were reopening, he grew up eating this pie when Garcia's was on Dale street in Normal IL, back when he was a teenager. He arrived from out of state on Monday 12/21/2015, and on Tuesday, he ordered a stuffed gut-buster pie with no onions, went to pick it up and they had made it a thin crust, he told them no that was not what he had ordered, and they told him it would be another 45 minutes to make the stuffed gut-buster with no onions. So he ran a couple errands  and picked up the pie and came back home, the pie was  as he remembered it, full to the top of the pan, no cardboard under the pie, golden crust, we cut it after the more than hour an and a half of waiting in anticipation, and  IT WAS FILLED WITH ONIONS ! I had to pick through the piece I had because of the onions. 
The taste was reminiscent of what our son remembered from when he last had Garcia's gut-buster, and one piece filled each of us up. So when our daughter arrived, also from out of state, our son told her that after he finally got his stuffed gut-buster, it was pretty much as he remembered, she and him decided that it would be great get 2 of them for lunch on Saturday 12/26/2015 to feed all of us before they both returned to the states they now live in. 
So our son called it in, and when they got there to pick the pies up, there was a sign stating "NO CASH CREDIT CARDS ONLY" (good thing our daughter was with our son, because he doesn't have a credit card and was going to pay cash for the pies) They got home with the pies, and when we opened the boxes, we were amazed, the pies didn't even fill half the depth of the pans, and this was with a round of cardboard under each pie (but they were unlike the filled to the brim pie we had gotten on Tuesday of the same week), The dough didn't look or taste fully cooked, and each of us had 2 pieces unlike Tuesdsay (where one piece filled us, and we had leftovers). He called and talked to the manager and he had to call back, because the manager didn't return his call, and the manager said he would credit the card for one pizza, so our daughter had to go back as she was heading out of town and back to her home state.  
I can't believe the inconsistency of the pies in the same week, and the errors that were made, also can't believe they weren't able to accept cash on Saturday, but I also must say that our son experienced a clear problem with someone not able to make change on Tuesday. The bill was $26.07 he gave her $27.00 (a $20., a $5. and 2 $1.'s then said "wait, I have the $.07", well what he had in change was $.12 so he gave her that and told her to give him back one of the $1. bills and his change, she couldn't understand that she needed to return a dollar bill and give him a nickel in change. She told him that she had never seen anyone make change like that, and she was sure that she should be keeping both dollar bills he had originally given her.  
If Garcia's Pizza hopes to prosper in this town (where there is an abundance of pizza joints), they better address the problems of the poor service, not having cash on hand, not being able to count change, and inconsistency of pies.
